sections.title: Welcome to the “Connecting the Dots” Challenge
Rethink Reading. Rediscover Knowledge
sections.summary: What if every time you opened a PDF, it didn’t just sit there—it spoke to you, connected ideas, and narrated meaning across your entire library? That’s the future we’re building — and we want you to help shape it.

sections.title: PDF as an intelligent, interactive experience—one that understands structure,
sections.summary: surfaces insights, and responds to you like a trusted research companion.

sections.title: The Journey Ahead
sections.summary: Round 1: Kick things off by building the brains — extract structured outlines from raw PDFs with blazing speed and pinpoint accuracy. Then, power it up with on-device intelligence that understands sections and links related ideas together.

sections.title: It’s showtime! Build a beautiful, intuitive reading webapp using Adobe’s
sections.summary: PDF Embed API. You will be using your Round 1 work to design a futuristic webapp.

sections.title: Why This Matters
sections.summary: In a world flooded with documents, what wins is not more content — it’s context. You’re not just building tools — you’re building the future of how we read, learn, and connect.

sections.title: Are you in?
sections.summary: It’s time to read between the lines. Connect the dots.

sections.title: Challenge Theme: Connecting the Dots Through Docs
Your Mission
sections.summary: You're handed a PDF — but instead of simply reading it, you're tasked with making sense of it like a machine would. Your job is to extract a structured outline of the document — essentially the Title, and headings like H1, H2, and

sections.title: H3 — in a clean, hierarchical format.
sections.summary: This outline will be the foundation for the rest of your hackathon journey.

sections.title: PDFs are everywhere — but machines don’t naturally understand their
sections.summary: structure. By building an outline extractor, you’re enabling smarter document experiences, like semantic search, recommendation systems, and insight generation.

sections.title: You must build a solution that:
sections.summary: Accepts a PDF file (up to 50 pages) Extracts: o Title o Headings: H1, H2, H3 (with level and page number) Outputs a valid JSON file in the format below: { "title": "Understanding AI", "outline": [ { "level": "H1", "text": "Introduction", "page": 1 }, { "level": "H2", "text": "What is AI?", "page": 2...

sections.title: Docker Requirements
sections.summary: Please ensure your Dockerfile is compatible with AMD64 architecture. Since we will build and run the image on an AMD64 machine, your base image and any dependencies should support linux/amd64.

sections.title: Dockerfile to explicitly specify the platform: FROM --
sections.summary: platform=linux/amd64 <base_image> CPU architecture: amd64 (x86_64) No GPU dependencies Model size (if used) ≤ 200MB Should work offline — no network/internet calls

sections.title: We will build the docker image using the following command:
sections.summary: ```docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t mysolutionname:somerandomidentifier``` After building the image, we will run the solution using the run command specified in the submitted instructions. ```docker run --rm -v $(pwd)/input:/app/input -v $(pwd)/output:/app/output -- network none mysolutionname...

sections.title: Your container should:
sections.summary: Automatically process all PDFs from /app/input directory, generating a corresponding filename.json in /app/output for each filename.pdf output.json

sections.title: Must run on CPU (amd64),
sections.summary: your solution should run on the system with 8 CPUs and 16 GB RAM configurations

sections.title: Pro Tips
sections.summary: Don’t rely solely on font sizes for heading level determination — headings in some PDFs break that assumption. Test your solution across both simple and complex PDFs.

sections.title: What Not to Do
sections.summary: Do not hardcode headings or file-specific logic Do not make API or web calls Do not exceed the runtime/model size constraints [[Public Dataset Folder]] (For Sample Input and Output Files, please refer to the appendix)
